lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six fruits and vegetables (grapes, watermelons, pumpkins, mushrooms, cucumbers, lemons) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Display fruit/veg flashcards. Say: “He’s got some grapes.” Students point to the picture. Then quiz: “Who’s got lemons?”
stretchStrategies: Students design a “Fruit & Veg Menu” in pairs, choosing 4–5 items with sentences like “She’s got some grapes. He hasn’t got any lemons.” They present their menus.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say simple statements about fruits and vegetables using “He’s/She’s got some...” / “He/She hasn’t got any...” and ask and answer questions using “What has he/she got?” / “He’s/She’s got some...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Use cutout characters. Students ask: “What has she got?” Partner answers with: “She’s got some pumpkins.” Do a mingle activity to ask multiple classmates.
stretchStrategies: Students design a “Fruit & Veg Menu” in pairs, choosing 4–5 items with sentences like “She’s got some grapes. He hasn’t got any lemons.” They present their menus.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “He’s/She’s got some ___.” / “He/She hasn’t got any ___.” and ask and answer using “What has he/she got?” / “He’s/She’s got some ___.” to talk about fruits and vegetables.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Board match: students sort sentence halves into positive and negative: “He’s got some ___” / “He hasn’t got any ___.” Then practise with realia or flashcards.

items: Food in syllabi typically Western-centric: banh mi >> bread
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
